conversation.content: [cold] You're Sarah Chen.

[stunned] Um, wait, what?

[bitter] Five years ago, December 14th, you processed evidence for the Thompson case and your, [shaking], mislabeling meant the blood sample from the actual crime scene got, [disgusted], swapped with blood from a minor assault case two blocks, [furious], away. [slams folder down]

No, that's not—I mean, um, I would never, uh, make that kind of mistake because I, [panicking], triple-check everything, I always have, and there's no way I could have, [desperate], confused those samples because they came in at, [frantic], different times that day.
[quietly] Marcus Thompson killed himself in prison last month after losing, [voice cracking], his final appeal.

[shocked] Oh my God, I remember that case now, but the evidence logs showed everything was, [searching memory], properly documented, and I specifically recall checking, [horrified], those particular samples myself.

[exhausted] The real killer confessed yesterday and provided details only someone at the scene would know, which forced us to review, [bitter], every piece of evidence, including your labels which clearly show, [accusatory], the wrong identification numbers written in your, [disgusted], handwriting. [revealing] Your supervisor at the time, Detective Morrison, admitted under questioning that he pressured you to process, [measured], forty-seven pieces of evidence in three hours that day to meet, [bitter], his deadline for the grand jury. [long pause]
[breaking down] Well, um, yes, he did pressure me but I still, uh, followed every protocol and if there was a mistake, [voice cracking], then I need to know how it happened.

Well, umm, the thing is, we found, uh, seventeen other cases from that same month where evidence labels show, [revealing], similar discrepancies, all processed during Morrison's shifts.
[stunned] Seventeen other cases with the same, [horrified], kind of labeling issues?
Morrison's been arrested this morning for evidence tampering, but that doesn't bring Marcus Thompson, [voice breaking], back or undo the damage to every case you two, [bitter], worked together.

I don't, um, I mean, I trusted him completely and, uh, never thought to question why he always insisted on, [realizing], reviewing my work alone after hours, and now I'm wondering how many times he, [horrified], changed my labels after I left. [sobbing]
